title: Mit Pulver eine richtig gute Sache. Mit Kapseln ganz okay
body:
Mein bisheriger Kenntnisstand: ich trinke gerne guten Kaffee und kann guten von schlechtem Kaffee unterscheiden. Bin aber kein Barista oder habe Kaffeebrühen studiert.

Ich habe bisher meinen Espresso mit einem simplen Vollautomaten gemacht und war so mittel begeistert davon. Da wir viel unterwegs sind, campen und Boot fahren, wollte ich diese Maschine für unterwegs mal ausprobieren.

Nachdem ich am ersten Nachmittag vier verschiedene Espresso probiert habe, konnte ich bis morgens um 3 Uhr Farben hören und zu Fuß Autos auf der Autobahn überholen, was erstmal weniger über den Geschmack des Kaffees aussagt.

Die Erkenntnis dieses experimentellen Nachmittages war in jedem Fall, dass der Kaffee aus der Wacaco Nanopresso und die Handhabung folgendermaßen zu bewerten ist:

Kapseln- je nach Kapselsorte guter Geschmack, aber sehr mühsam und langsam zu pumpen. Es ist ein deutlich höherer Druck erforderlich, um das Wasser durch die Kapsel zu bekommen. Probleme mit dem anstechen gab es aber nicht, wie sie hier manchmal beschrieben wurden. Bisher auch nicht mit Kapseln anderer Hersteller, als die originalen.

Pulver-
Ich hatte anfangs bedenken, da mich das ganze Drumherum der ganzen Kaffeeprofessoren mit den Feinwagen und anderen speziellen Techniken verunsichert hatte, ob die Zubereitung mit Pulver zu kompliziert werden könnte. Da man dazu diesen praktischen Pulverlöffel bekommt, der gleichzeitig zum andrücken des Pulvers genutzt werden kann/sollte, ist das ganze eigentlich kinderleicht. Man kann Sieb und Löffel passgenau aufeinander stecken, damit beim umfüllen kein Krümel daneben geht und schon hat man ganz sauber und einfach das Pulver eingefüllt. Das Wasser lässt sich in dem Fall auch im Vergleich zu den Kapseln einfach durch das Pulver pumpen und als Lohn erhält man einen sehr guten Espresso oder mit etwas mehr Wasser im Tank auch einen doppelten.

Zur Temperatur:
Ja, wenn man es falsch macht, erhält man nur lauwarmen Espresso. Aber wenn man ganz heißes Wasser einfüllt und am besten noch die Tasse mit einem kleinen Schluck heißen Wassers vorwärmt, wird es alles heiß genug.

Genau das richtige für unterwegs, im Camper, im Zelt, auf der Arbeit oder eben auf dem Boot.
Die Qualität der Maschine erscheint erstmal sehr wertig und gut. Negative Langzeiterfahrungen würde ich später anfügen, wenn es denn welche gibt. Bisher bin ich guter Dinge, dass der Apparillo noch lange hält.

title: tres bonne macine expresso manuelle
body:
J'ai acheté la nanopresso pour dosettes nespresso.
Très satisfait !
- J'avais déjà eu un modele handpresso avec dosettes souples. C'atait très lent et le gout du café dosettes n'atait pas terrible
- J'avais ensuite acheté une handpresso auto capsule (capsules nespresso) sur 12V : ca fait un très bon café mais il faut une source de 12V, et le chauffage et la mise en pression est longue (>3 min), donc ce n'est pas pratique quand on a plusieurs expressos à faire.
- Ce modèle totalement manuel necessite de faire chauffer de l'aeu mais sur un réchaud de caming c'est rapide. Ensuite une fois l'eau (très) chaude, il ne faut que 40 secondes pour faire l'expresso.

Le gout est bon, un peu en dessous de ce qu'on obtient avec une machine 220V nespresso, mais c'est vraiment tout à fait acceptable (surtout en utilisation nomade, quel plaisir de degsuter un expresso plutot qu'un sachet de café lyophilisé !!)

2 petites astuces :
- faire couler une 1ere fois "à blanc " avec l'eau bouillante ; cela permet de préchauffer la cafetiere, et on laisse couler l'aeu dans la tasse, ce qui la préchauffe.
Ensuite même manip mais avec la capsule : le café sera très chaud au moment de le deguster (car c'est un reproche que l'on fait à cette machine vu les diférents avis : céfé pas très chaud...)
- a la mise en pression, dès que les 1eres gouttes coulent, arreter de pomper 10 secondes pour laisser infuser la capsule, puis reprendre le pompage : le gout sera meilleur

Donc au final : je suis très content de cette machine. Elle est très compacte,d'utilisation facile et rapide , et expresso de bonne qualité.
J'ai choisi (j'entends déjà les reproches des amateurs de vrai expresso) l'option capsule nespresso. C'est tellement plus facile, plus rapide aussi, et plus facile à nettoyer.

Seul décéption : pas d'offre black friday pour la toucher à un meilleur tarif

title: Portable and Brilliant
body:
I bought this so my wife and I could have decent coffee whilst away from home. This is a compact machine that is very easy to use and also to clean. I have used it with NS capsules and also cheaper versions and both have been good. I did have an issue when I 1st used it as one of the capsules seemed to open incorrect and coffee grains went everywhere. I contacted customer service who were very helpful and suggested not tightening the end where the capsule goes too much, I took their advice and have had no problems since.
I have found that filling the water cup using the machine and then filling again still gives a good cup of coffee and also a larger cup. The pump is easy to use and after about 6 pushes the pressure builds and then the pod pops and coffee comes out. I would suggest not pumping too vigorously as this is also what may have caused the problem I had. Do be aware though that this machine does not heat the water so you will need either a kettle or something else that can boil water.
All in all this has been an excellent purchase and I am really pleased with it.
I can’t leave any feedback on using the filter coffee option as I haven’t used this as I prefer the capsules.

I had a problem with the first adapter (for using pods, not grounds) not puncturing the pods, so no water flowed through the pod. I asked a question online and one answer suggested that I had a defective unit. I returned/exchanged for a new one, and sure enough, that was the problem. The new adapter has longer spikes which puncture just fine.
The plastic parts are pretty thick, seem as if they won’t break any time soon. Took me awhile to figure out where the cup that was pictured is. It’s the outer shell of the water container, you have to wiggle, not unscrew, to get it off. I just carry a small insulated cup with the unit which I think works better. But the unit really does have everything you need, except the coffee and the water heater.

title: Great quality built with some drawbacks
body:
First of all this unit is smaller than expected and is a neat little product. The built quality is great and the plastic feels solid in your hands. There are only pros on the product side.

But does it do good coffee? Well it depends. If you use your own grounded coffee you’ll have to find the right grains, grounded at the right thickness for the foam to appear and for the coffee to taste good. Plus handling the coffee beans is a messy business, especially if you use this in the wilderness.

So I would recommend using the nespresso pod adaptor to make your coffee. Using the nespresso adaptor, the coffee was not bad and produced a lot of foam.

Unless you like single shot espressos, you’ll probably have to invest in the barista kit to have a bigger water container. Alternatively you can pour 2 cups but this just makes the process messier and not as convenient.

All in all, this is a nice gadget if you need your coffee anywhere you are.

title: NS adapter must have for Nespresso user
body:
I bought this bundle because I already have a Nespresso original machine at home and buy bulk nespresso pods. So this version with the included adapter is perfect for on the go easy extraction and no mess clean up. Fast, convenient and really good espresso to boot!

Users need to be reminded that the water reservoir needs to be screwed on tight before pumping! Or else the boiling water will leak out and potentially burning your hands.

Another trick to use the nespresso pods properly is when screwing close the apparatus with the nespresso pod already in the adapter, do so quickly to ensure the pod is punctured thoroughly on both sides, otherwise you will feel/hear a muted pop, when you start to pump, that means the tinfoil side of the pod wasn't punctured properly. The pop means the tinfoil is now burst open under pressure and may cause some coffee grinds to come out with the drink.

It is recommended to use nespresso pods that are designed for espresso with more weight, that will mean the pods are packed more fully and the tinfoil side less likely to "pop", but it also means it's likely a darker espresso. Alternatively, one can use lungo pods, where the grinds are more coarse, and less likely to come out even if the tinfoil side is "pop"ed.

The NS adapter with the smooth metal band, make it very hard to remove in order to do a proper cleaning. I get nespresso branding is important, but there should be some sort of jimping on the metal band to allow more purchase on the adapter and make taking it apart easier.

The only other downside, is that the entire setup even though mostly plastic, is still quite heavy at 1lb. 1lb may not sound like a lot to most people but since this thing will likely be used by a lot of campers/hikers/outdoor lovers. Every ounce counts. Maybe a luxury edition featuring carbon fibre hull with titanium innards someday? Espresso is already a luxury items when out hiking/backpacking, so making it a bit more expensive and a lot lighter will attract the most avid backpacker who loves espresso.

title: Yep, does it for me
body:
I started with an Aeropress and then went for an Oomph. Both worked fine but I fancied a change and I like messing with new stuff so I went for this.

Really nicely made and easy enough to put together. I use it at work and probably make 3 or 4 coffees a day, running 2 lots of water through to get a double.

You definitely get a nice crema on your coffee. I've got a decent bean to cup espresso machine at home and this is as good as that, I'd say.

It's a little bit fiddly to clean but probably no different to any other of this sort of thing. It's easy enough to use with 2 hands and I can just about use it with 1 but then I haven't got the biggest hands and I'm sure it's practical if that's important to you.

I use ground coffee all the time. I bought the Nespresso adapter as part of the bundle because I used to have a Nespresso machine and thought it would be convenient. I bought some pods and tried it but I think if you're used to bean to cup then it's almost like going back to instant coffee. I'll probably use it if I run out of ground and will keep a few pods as a backup but I don't think I'd use it all the time.

I'm also going to order the larger water tank. It's not too much inconvenience filling it twice but it would just be a bit quicker to be able to do a double in one go and keeping it small isn't a priority for me.

The downside is the price. With this and the barista kit you're looking at just over £100 for something to make a cup of coffee. I guess if you swap from buying a coffee at £2.50 a pop to this which costs pennies then you'll get your money back quite quickly but it still feels like a lot to spend on something like this.

title: High quality and great taste!
body:
I just received my Nanopresso with the Nespresso adaptor in the afternoon and had to try it! I bought cheap pods, not the original ones, and made myself a very long coffe, about 175 ml, 1 pod only, and used the Nanovessel which I bought at the same time, so I had a lot of water in it, actually I wasn't expecting much but it tasted much better than expected, not weak at all and not bitter. I am impressed. It was also very hot; I simply ran hot tap water by itself i the machine before I did my coffee with boiling water. It was actually more hot than the coffe from our fully automatic Saeco machine.

I'm glad the cheap non-Nespresso pods work (top is aluminum and bottom plastic) as when I travel in hotels and work a few hours in the morning I know I will go through a lot!

The machine design is well thought of and I don't feel anything needs to be improved; you feel the quality and every part fits well into another and feel sturdy. It is also easy to clean (I used the pod so it makes it easier for sure).

Pumping is fine; it is not hard to pump at all. You have to pump many times to get a long coffee but I don't see this as an issue.

The Nanovessel is just as nicely built as the rest; so is the Barista kit, which I also bought! No leak (like I saw on some reviews).

Everything works as expected, and better; I will make some out of grind coffee tomorrow.

title: Et, en plus, c'est le meilleur café que j'aie jamais tiré d'une capsule !
body:
Produit tout à fait surprenant dont je ne me sépare plus.

Très pratique en voyage : une capsule et il suffit de chauffer de l'eau (de Volvic, par exemple) sur le réchaud de camping (alcool, pastille "esbit" ou autre...) pour avoir un café *bien meilleur* qu'avec les cafetières électriques proposées par la principale marque de capsules ! Je n'ai aucune explication logique à ce fait mais nous sommes plusieurs amateurs de café à l'avoir constaté sur des capsules de différentes marques (Nespresso, Lobodis, Terre de café, Cap mundo...)

L'ensemble prend peu de place, même dans un sac à dos et n'est pas bien lourd. Je conseillerais l'étui proposé en option car fort pratique, justement, dans le sac à dos... ou à l'extérieur, avec un petit mousqueton. Prévoir aussi quelques chiffons pour essuyer l'appareil avant de le ranger.

La démultiplication du "pompage" est très bien étudiée et on ne force pas du tout.

Petit défaut : le "chargeur à capsules" gratte un peu en vissant, peut-être un léger défaut d'usinage, ça ne gêne pas le fonctionnement mais c'est dommage.

À noter. Attention : on manipule l'eau très chaude, avec un peu d'inattention, j'ai réussi à me brûler légèrement aux doigts. Par ailleurs, certaines capsules, parfois, ne "percent" pas, l'eau coule autour de la capsule. Un petit coup de pointe de couteau dans la pellicule et ça marche.

J'ai eu un produit similaire mais pour "capsules souples" et qui ressemble à une pompe à vélo. Pas pratique du tout et café sans caractère. Je m'en suis servi deux ou trois fois et l'ai oublié dans un placard.

Je n'ai pas encore testé avec du café fraîchement moulu (sans l'option "capsule"), ce que je ferai une fois rentré chez moi... à bientôt donc :)

Si mon commentaire vous a plu, cliquez sur "j'aime" :)

title: My Life is Complete
body:
I can’t say enough good about this little gem. It kicks out some amazing espresso. I suppose everyone has their thing. Mine? I screw on my double espresso ring from the barista kit, grab a double basket (also from the kit), leave on the water reservoir that came with the Nanopresso and squeeze out a double. Then I top it off with a bit of frothy milk. It does take a little getting used to the correct amount of grind etc. but it doesn’t take long to figure out what works best for you. You just don’t want to overfill the basket, or over tamp your grind. I also purchased the Nespresso attachment and have really enjoyed trying several different Nespresso pods.

*UPDATE*
Well, the honeymoon is over. When I use my own grind, it works really well, but recently I’ve been having issues with the NS Adapter. It has decided not to pierce the foil on the top of the Nespresso capsules no matter what I do. If it doesn’t change in the next pod or two, I’ll have to use my Asurian Protection Plan.

*UPDATE TO THE UPDATE*
First, I have to say that customer service has been great. They have answered my e-mails promptly with suggestions and even a video made for me demonstrating a couple of ideas to fix mt NS adapter issue. Here’s what I think was happening... When I placed the Nespresso pod into the unit, I would just screw the cap on without pressing the pod down onto the cutting blades. I think it was kind of grabbing the pod and twisting it before it was completely down on the blades. Anyway, what I have done with the last four or five pods is press them firmly down onto the blades before twisting the cap on. It’s worked like a champ every time.

La máquina es muy buena para café molido, pero no para las cápsulas. Conseguía un café bueno de cada 10 con las cápsulas. La cápsula no se rompe adecuadamente y el agua se atasca, saliendo por dónde puede, menos atravesando la cápsula. Total que sale algo de café y bastante de agua. Lo que se consigue es un café aguado.

La probé durante 2 semanas y la devolví por este problema. Cuando rompe la cápsula adecuadamente el café es muy bueno. Mejor que con la cafetera automática de Nespresso que tengo.

En cuanto al café molido hay que molerlo fino para que salga bien. Pero es mucho más fácil que salga bien que con la cápsula.

title: My Go to Coffee Solution
body:
I purchased the Nanopresso bundled with the Nespresso Adapter. I then purchased separately the barista kit. Through the recommendation of another reviewer, I also purchased the Zwilling Sorrento double wall glasses. Perfect for espresso and the case that's molded for the nanopresso. I recommend that but it all adds up...

My situation is that I work overseas and in rougher environments. I do a lot of traveling so that's how I justify this to myself. My goal is to be able to make decent coffee on the go with little fuss and this coffee kit does this really really well.

At first I found it to be just a bit intimidating with all parts that I wound up with, but you figure it out. There are youtube videos that explain how to set it up. The first time I pumped it, It was a little awkward but you get used to it. For something that's not powered this is pretty cool. You just need some hot water. I've read other reviews and a concern was the water leaking or maybe it wasn't screwed on well. I didn't have that issue with my device. You just have to make sure you screw everything on correctly.

So after the first espresso, using the Nespresso adapter, i saw the crema form and the taste was great! I realized then that if it holds up, this can be an everyday solution and so far, it really has been. I not only use this everyday, but I haven't used my coffee pot or any other coffee device since I've purchased this.
I drink like 4 cups a day.

Now I'm not a supreme coffee aficionado. I went into this with middle of the road expectations half wondering if I may have wasted my money because some may say its pricey gadget but so far, this device has really performed well and especially when I think about how small and convenient this is and again, it's non-powered. This is a very cool solution.

If you are on the road. No mess. No fuss. Easy to maintain. I think it's engineered very well. Its durable made out of this hard plastic. Very solid. I carry it with me in my backpack that's like a portable locker for me that I half live out of. So this thing is EDC for me. It's just so nice to be able to breakout coffee whenever and wherever I want.

The other aspect I enjoy is that this nanopresso saves me from using shared spaces like breakrooms and just running into who dunnit cleanup situations with coworkers.

If you want to get away from sharing things with others especially with the concern of viruses, germs and what not. I say consider this device.

Avoid the breakrooms or getting stuck in traffic trying to do a coffee run in the middle of your work day. Overall its a really nice coffee solution if your okay with the price. Enjoy.

title: Had 2 units now, and both failed
body:
When I first started using this product, I took it everywhere. Hotels, camping, even to mates' houses when I knew they'd only be serving instant coffee. It's very easy to use, and perfectly fits Nespresso pods. The unit is a good size and was thrilled with it. Takes about 30 seconds of plunging to make an espresso, but paired with the right pods, it was as good as any machine could delivery.

After a few months, however, the plunger started not springing back ready for the next press once you've done one shot. I usually like a double espresso, so by the time I'd put in the second capsule and started plunging with a new tank of hot water, each press required me to pull the plunger back with a nail before I could press again. After doing that repeatedly until the water is used up, I can tell you that patience wears thin and your coffee becomes cold!

To be fair to them, WACACO support very quickly dispatched a replacement, but sadly after just 3 months the second one started doing exactly the same. It's just like there is defect when you try to do more than one pod in a short space of time, and it feels as though it's the heat that is making it expand something inside so that it fails to plunge.

So my delight at £80 well spent is now just irritation that I have purchased a sub-standard product. After my experience of 2 such devices, I would not be able to recommend you waste your money, and perhaps look for a newer model.

title: Cracked!
body:
I make my living traveling, and I enjoy a good coffee where I can get one, but having coffee shop decent coffee gets expensive all the time. We have a Nespresso at home, so I figured this portable espresso maker would work well as an extension of what we already have - I wouldn’t have to cart around espresso and all the accouterments required to pack and clean espresso grounds - I could pop in a pod and some hot water and go! And it worked! The coffee is exactly what I expect from my nespresso ar home. It’s simple enough, makes a nice shot of espresso (I recommend running a little hot water through it once without coffee in it to pre-heat the plumbing. The shot comes out much hotter, with more crema, and more flavorful if you do this!) Cleaning is easy, though I do note some complaints here about cleaning the device...seriously? I feel like people making these comments have never made espresso before. It ALWAYS requires cleanup unless you’ve got some automatic machine, and it’s pretty obvious that this is not that kind of device. So yeah, cleanup’s not fun, but you’re saving $3+ per espresso drink and making up for it with a little elbow grease. Fair enough? At any rate this review seems like I really like the device (I do), so why the 2 stars?

It cracked. I found out when I was making a shot and poured the hot water into the tank-cup. As it sealed upon insertion it shot hot water all over me and my hand as the seal applied pressure. I got somewhat scalded, and wet. I haven’t even made a couple dozen shots with it yet. I have broken no “rules” regarding the prep and use of the device, it’s not been overheated or stressed. For something at this price range I expected better, and I expected it to pay for itself in coffee savings several times over before failure. It hasn’t lived up to those expectations. I now have an unusable espresso maker.

Caveat emptor.

title: Don't even dream of buying this stupid thing.
body:
Wacoco's Nanopresso takes the ease of use of a Nespresso machine and does a complete 180°, turning the brewing of a single capsule into a science experiment.

Wacaco's first gen product, the Minipresso, was complicated enough for me to put away after one or two dozen capsules and never touch again. This new and "improved" model takes the complexity to a new low. There are numerous components, some tiny, requiring disassembly for cleaning, the directions are incomplete, and I had to wipe up an impressively wide swath of coffee grounds from my kitchen counter. It's a good trick to be able to screw up a prepackaged capsule, but this device pulls that off nicely.

I'm giving this device two stars since some of the people using it with ground coffee have apparently had more success. But if I were going camping, an Aeropress would be my choice of coffee device to pack.

On rare occasion a product pisses me off to such an extent that I have to initiate the return instantly, and get it out of my sight as quickly as possible. This is one such item. Begone!

Nach der ersten Zeit ca. 3 Monaten hatte ich aber schon den Eindruck dass nicht alles dicht ist, da der Espresso nicht mehr so gut gelungen war mit gleichen Kapseln wie vorher und auch ab und an der Kaffee an der Seite heraus lief.
Ich habe die Wacaco nach jeder Verwendung gereinigt und getrocknet.
Nun nach ca. 6 Monaten fließt der Kaffee nur noch ohne sichtbare Pause durch, so dass ich den Eindruck habe, dass der Druck nicht mehr richtig ausgebaut wird. Anfangs kam der Espresso nur bei jedem Pumpendruck, nun fließt er nach den ersten Drücken einfach raus. Zudem fliesst der Kaffee mittlerweile nicht mehr nur unten aus den dafür vorgesehenen Löchen sondern aus dem gesamten unteren grossen Loch auch rechts und links vom eigentlichen Ausfluss vorbei.
Leider hat mich die Langlebigkeit der Wacaco nicht übberzeugen können da diese meines Erachtens nach nur 6 Monaten zu früh deutlich in der Espressoqualität nachgelassen hat.
Sehr schade, da ich die Anfangsqualität sehr gut fand.

title: Could be great but lands on mediocre
body:
I’ve used this espresso maker on a weekly basis over the last 6 months before writing a review.

Pros:
Compact
Diverse-grounds or cups
Electric free
Little to 0 waste if desired
Cost effective

Cons:
Piston gets stuck requiring a knife to unstick from in position making it a PITA to use—even when not locked
Grams per cup single/double not accurate
Always water left in cup no matter if used for grounds or cup
Never hot enough, even with recommended prepping and running a cycle of hot water

I have recommended this initially to a few people. I have rescinded that to most of those few due to my issue with the piston getting stuck. It makes for pretty inconvenient espresso making in the morning while prepping all other things. It works in a pinch, if your electricity is down, camping, and so you don’t have to spend big bucks on a larger electric machine. I’m tempted to get a regular old pot that can go on the stove or camping stove; not as compact however I wonder if it would be more fruitful between time and waste. You’re also supposed to clean the mesh screen every couple of months however they do not provide needed screwdriver.

I very, very hesitantly recommend this espresso maker with the understanding that your piston may go to sh it with time.

——————————————————
I had a minipresso for a long time and loved it, eventually with some fairly hard use the pump gave in and leaked water. I bought this full of expectation obviously thinking it would be an improvement and maybe if you use coffee grounds it is but for Nespresso pods it’s a complete disaster. When you pump the water through you get the pop that it’s pushed through the foil of the capsule but then you get a cup of coffee grinds. I’d say it works one out of four times.

I wrote to Wacao for advise and they sent some half baked videos of the exact method to follow (non of which was required with the minipresso which just worked)

The instructions make no difference.

I went back to the minipresso for a few months and put up with the leaking pump but it’s finally failed totally. I’ve gone back to this unit and well it’s a waste of effort.

It’s beautifully made the flask is a great idea but it just doesn’t work with the capsules.

I’ve several colleagues who also bought this and also have bought this unit. All have the same issue.

I’ve given up and am reluctantly asking wacao for a return.

title: Great coffee! some problems with caps
body:
The first one was defective and returned it. Ordered a 2nd nanopresso and it worked fine but was experiencing problems using with capsules.
Gave it a 4 stars because coffee was amazing! I'm using it everyday with the capsules and making my own lattes.

With the Nespresso orginal capsules and M&S compatible ones, they work fine and don't need too much strength to pump through the pressure. However, if you're using L'or ones, you'll get a problem.

The L'or capsules are harder to puncture and I'm this close to breaking the pump handle with the amount of force I need. It works easily if I used a toothpick and put 2 small holes on the aluminium foil of the caps and havnt had a problem ever since - if you're experiencing the same problem, give it a try! I don't notice any taste difference by puncturing the foil slightly but I'm no coffee expert.

The nanopresso by itself is easy to clean and store, makes great espresso for my lattes, I love it so much that I might just buy another one for my parents! they could use it during travelling. The parts and device? on its own is quite sturdy, would give 5 stars if there wasn't the defective and capsules problem initially, I was so upset.

What I don't like is lukewarm or cold coffee unless I make cold coffee. I expected the same temperature of the water that I put in to be the same coming out. I knew there was going to be some loss because of thermal transfer. I just didn't expect it to this degree. I did find a third-party vendor that provides a stainless flask to replace the one provided by the manufacturer that screws directly to the unit. It also increases the quantity of water you can use for a double shot. The taste of the espresso is great and doesn't suffer too much because of the change in temperature but it still comes down to preference. Great for camping. Extremely compact and portable. title: Houston We Have Landed
body: I cannot believe they actually created such a product like this. This is absolutely unbelievable. How many of you love espresso coffee black? Maybe with or without sugar. For me I don't drink coffee or espresso without cream and sugar. Can't stand black coffee espresso because it is usually too bitter. However this Nanopresso will change your mind. I love drinking the espresso black still with some sugar. You get incredible rich crema that taste no different than spending hundred's if not a thousand plus on a machine. It almost tastes like cream was added but it's not. It is the 18 millibar pressure that squeezes incredible flavor out of the coffee. Not only this and this is where I just can't wrap my brain around this one. There is zero bitter taste! I have had other espresso machines and you get that espresso bitter taste in your pallet. No way in the world a starbucks esspresso taste as good as this little device can make. Plus it is portable so you can take it with you. I cannot understand why this has not been one of those CES inventions of the year. This is truly a man on the moon invention. And then you get the price. Seriously? Unbelievable inexpensive! I have waited a while to review this product because I wanted to run it through my tests. I use this every day. Try making cappuccinos with a good frother for the milk and there is no need to go to starbucks. Personally if I was the CEO of starbucks I would buy out the company just so that they would never sell another unit. This is a game changer and a threat to the big coffee outlets. Could only give it five stars because that is all the stars amazon gives. It is worth 10 stars. Do I love this product. Yes. And it is not hype. Try it for yourself.

title: Gute Entscheidung
body:

Sie macht einen extrem leckeren Kaffee mit beeindruckender Crema. Natürlich ist es etwas mühsam, auf einer Radtour mit Freunden vier Espressi zu pumpen, aber auch hier ist der Weg ein Teil des Zieles.
Die nanopresso liefert so viel Druck, dass der Trester richtig hart verpresst wird. Nicht ganz einfach, den Trester aus dem Siebeinsatz wieder herauszubekommen. Ich nehme meistens ein Taschenmesser oder einen Löffelstiel zu Hilfe.
Dn NS Träger habe ich noch nicht ausprobiert. Macht aber ebenfalls einen guten Eindruck.
Die einzige kleine Enttäuschung beim Auspacken war, dass dem Gerät für Aufbewahrung und Transport lediglich ein einfacher Stoffbeutel beilag. Ich hatte auf einem unboxing Video ein etwas höhenwertiges Case gesehen. Aber OK, damit kann ich leben.
Freunde von uns haben eine Handpresso PUMP. Sie waren von der nanopresso sehr beeindruckt und fanden deren Crema auch besser und leckerer.

title: It is what you need for your caffeine hit in the wild
body:
I was hesitant when I first read about this portable espresso maker. I struggle to believe most reviews I read as they are too commercial or written by challenged reviewers with zero common sense. I took the leap as I wanted to entice my girl to enjoy the outdoors. I am a serious outdoors guy...she is a little more glampy.

The WACACO Nanopresso Portable Espresso Maker works really well. It does what it is supposed to do. With a bit of practice, you can start to gauge correct right water temp and the required amount of "speed/pressure" to extract the espresso, to achieve the perfect crema. You really can get a fantastic shot of espresso, better than most local coffee huts.

When you prepare your last shot of espresso, add a bit more water to allow you to clean the parts and maintain the espresso maker for its next use.

Three camping trips, 30+pods.....it has rocked.....and the girl is happy.

Have fun!

title: Real espresso...
body:
I still can't believe it actually works so well.
No battery or power needed. Just a pressure pump for coffee. 18 bars. Double the amount of pressure that an espresso even needs... I didn't add anything else in the cup on this picture, this is the way it comes out and it tastes just as good as it looks!
All you need is boiled water and a fine grind of your preferred coffee (and a capsule if you're a capsule person, not me though).
You put coffee. You pour water. Seal tight. And start pumping. 15-20 pumps, a few drops of coffee and the delicious thick foam comes out.
It is magical. Works better than some of the espresso machines I've had in the past. Come to think of it, it does a better cup of espresso than 90% of the cafes in Berlin...

title: Great alternative while camping.
body:
I cannot live without my morning espresso. I have a nespresso machine at home, in my cabin and in my office, until now I did not have one in my car... This is now the case :)
Seriously, I'm an espresso junky and this minipresso machines relieves some of the pain of camping.
Ease of use : 10/10 Very practical, you don't have to be Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson strong to press your coffee.
Ease of cleaning : 10/10 there is no "too small" part that you may easily lose, cleaning is straightforward.
Taste : 7/10 again, I'm an espresso ass. I found the coffee (I am using nespresso pods) less intense in flavors than when I use a nespresso machine, but for a camping trip it is awesome. However, the crema is rich and beautiful! That intensity loss may be because of the water temperature and some comments suggested to buy the thermos adapter. I will try that for my next camping trip.
Conclusion : I love it, even if it is not "as good" as a proper nespresso machine, it does the job when you can't have one!

body: I took this on holiday and used it with coffee pods and a freshly boiled kettle. Of course it's more of a faff than a machine, but the taste and flavour was all there and satisfied my craving without having to leave the hotel room. I started by warming my cup with hot water and running boiling water through the wacaco. I then ran it through with the pod twice. I used instant milk powder which just stirred in without having to pre-mix. This all produced a perfect cup of hot coffee. All very portable and clean up was easy because I used pods. I don't think I would use with a flask of hot water, but would make it at the source of the hot water where I could pre warm the flask and then fill with coffee.

title: Taking my coffee with me just got easier!
body:
The Nanopresso looked like a cool gadget, but I already have a manual espresso machine, so why get another one? Then I read a comment that said there was a Nespresso capsule adapter for the Nanopresso. Okay, now I "need" this espresso machine!

I'm impressed with the packaging for the Nanopresso plus NS adapter. I like that the instructions for use are on the outer sleeve as well as on the individual boxes. The instructions on the boxes were a little tough to read because of the dark text on black background, but it was nice to see them anyway. There are also instruction books included with each item that are easier to read.

The machine works well. My espresso shots didn't look quite as good as in videos (not enough 'crema'), but with practice I'm sure I'll figure out the best pumping speed and timing to get better looking espresso shots. For now, I'm just happy to have a portable machine that works with my Nespresso capsules. And if I decide to use ground coffee instead, it's very easy to switch between the NS adapter and the regular Nanopresso top.
